awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Sodium (Na) Lidar Validation of MIGHTI Daytime Temperature Observations Onboard NASA ICON Satellite
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding to support an effort to achieve ground truth validation of Michelson Interferometer for Global High-resolution Thermospheric Imaging (MIGHTI) Ionospheric Connection Explorer (ICON) mesopause measurements near 95km to resolve an issue suggesting the existence of a bias in the comparisons of MIGHTI measurements with Utah State Sodium (Na) lidar daytime climatological measurements. The ICON satellite view of the northern hemisphere may be reversed toward the southern hemisphere. This would mean that the possibility of overflight measurements by MIGHTI that are simultaneous with the Utah State University (USU) daytime lidar measurements would not be feasible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Exploring the earth upper atmosphere from space has great advantage to study the climate and interactions between the atmosphere and geospace. As one of the most important atmospheric dynamic parameters, the atmospheric temperature above ~90 km is very difficult to measure, however. The MIGHTI instrument on board the NASA ICON satellite, launched in October 2019, conducts global temperature observations in the upper atmosphere. Thus, it is critical to validate these temperature data by an indepentent instrument so that the ongoing and future scientific studies that utilize the MIGHTI data can be confident about the fidelity of the satellite observations. In this project, a ground-based advanced lidar system at Utah State University with the capability of temperature observations in the same atmopsheric region is used to validate the ICON/MIGHTI temperature observations, especially the spacecraft's unique daytime measurements.

The lidar team organized a couple of multi-day campaigns to measure the temperature simultaneously during the overpass of the spacecraft, attaining close to 200 hours of daytime data and several hundred of hours nighttime observations. Although some biases are noticed when comparing the lidar temperatures with those of the ICON/MIGHTI, the overall performance of the MIGHTI instrument is healthy and its temperature measurements are reliable. This validation work is presented in two peer-reviewed journal publications and the data are available for public.
